Story: The closest thing my daughter, Ella, could get to a pandemic pet was a Venus flytrap (named Venus). Ella won a scholarship to boarding school and left last August. I lit candles for Venus and collected rainwater for her. Taking care of Ellaâs fragile plant was as close as I could get to taking care of her. In the winter I thought Venus was dead. No, just dormant. I moved her to a cooler place and waited for spring. And then, a slender stem! A mouth and even teeth coming soon. Who said these girls are fragile? â Sharon Harrigan
Author: Sharon Harrigan

Story: My sister and I werenât close growing up. The oldest of seven, Barbara was bookish, while I, the second oldest, couldnât sit still â always playing hopscotch and tag outside our Bronx apartment. When Barbara left for Bennington College, the elder-sibling responsibilities fell on me. To escape, I started visiting her in Vermont. Suddenly in a less diverse environment, Barbara missed me. Thus began our very intimate relationship that spanned 50 years. Cancer took her last April. One thing we loved to do together was walk. Now when I take my daily walk, I feel her presence. â Beverly Abercrombie
Author: Beverly Abercrombie

Story: It was all too much. Another semester, no progress on my dissertation, three jobs, endless exams to grade, and my only son had forgotten my birthday â again. I curled on the couch and cried fat, self-absorbed tears. When nothing my husband did helped â no begging, soothing or promising my favorite foods â he put his forehead against mine and wept with me. By joining me in my desolation, he made me feel less desolate. â Renee Goethe
Author: Renee Goethe

Story: Early on, lying in bed after moving into our Manhattan apartment, I asked Mary, âDo you think weâll be this happy in 20 years?â I had barely finished the question when she blurted, âNo.â We laughed, but I knew she would always be my person, and I hers. As we approach 20 years, I sit in our bed, now in Brooklyn, and consider our happiness. Weâve lived through deaths of parents, sperm donor selections, births of children, emotional distance, crankiness, counseling and menopause. We remain âMary and Robinâ â each otherâs person, savoring a deeper and different happiness. â Robin Hopkins
Author: Robin Hopkins

Story: Before the city pool in Johnson City, Tenn., got drained at summerâs end, dogs could take a swim for five bucks. Sporting his green life jacket, Barney leapt in as if he werenât tired, deaf, toothless. We stayed until no one else was left. Itâs a small thing in life, a dog, but small is relative. I packed biscuits for our last trip to the vet. I sat on the floor in the lobby, feeding Barney biscuits one by one, and for a moment it seemed possible that we might never run out. â Shuly XÃ³chitl Cawood
Author: Shuly XÃ³chitl Cawood

Story: The scene is tranquil. My face grazes Mamaâs arm as she lights five candles. No ordinary cake would do. She spent hours making this richly layered EszterhÃ¡zy torte with pretty puffs of whipped cream. In Canada, her new home, we celebrated my birth and life. We celebrated me â the daughter she had not dared to imagine at 17, when she was alone, desperate to survive, hiding in Budapestâs bombed buildings and basements, terrified of being discovered by the Nazis. For years Iâd challenged Mama for being overprotective. Later I understood. I represented the living, breathing embodiment of survival. â Janet Horvath
Author: Janet Horvath

Story: When I moved in with Sheila in 1979, she asked, âSo do you want to do grocery shopping or laundry?â Without a beat, I said, âGrocery shopping.â More than 40 years of marriage later, I still do the grocery shopping and Sheila does the laundry. When our boys were toddlers, I started taking them shopping with me so that they would be good shoppers and know that lifeâs chores are a shared responsibility â and an act of care. â Zachary Gilstein
Author: Zachary Gilstein

Story: I woke up to images of mass cremations in your country. I remembered it was your birthday and texted you my wishes and worries. You said you were OK, remarking, âWhat a paradox it is to be connected despite 8,000 miles of distance.â We negotiate the separation by chattering through phone static, like ghosts through a wall. Itâs hard to imagine you sheltering in your Mumbai apartment. Opening my phoneâs map for help, I see us: Two blue dots on one blue planet, gradients of ocean and sky between us. Weâre both still here, and I am grateful. â AnaÃ¯s La Rocca
Author: AnaÃ¯s La Rocca

Story: I fry cutlets for chicken parmigiana, doing math: In my 53 years, I have fried thousands. My mother taught me. When I was 7, we would fry chicken side by side, her hip touching mine. âCover yourself,â she would say. âYouâll get hurt and dirty that shirt.â As a teenager, Iâd snap, âMa, I hate when you use âdirtyâ as a verb.â But, no matter the age, I would listen and grab an apron. More math: Itâs been over two decades without her. But still, like magic, she reminds me to separate the cutlets and back away from the flame. â Kathy Curto
Author: Kathy Curto

Story: My abuela raised me, her first grandson, in Santiago in the 1970s, while my parents worked to support us. Then, when I was 6, we moved to Melbourne. I missed my abuela. When I was 15, she visited us in our new country, where she didnât speak the language but still bargained at the market. At 24 and beginning law school, I returned to Santiago. My abuela cooked me lunch every day. A practicing lawyer at 40, I returned in time to say goodbye at her bedside. My family doesnât say âI love you,â yet by my being there, I think she knew. â Miguel Belmar Salas
Author: Miguel Belmar Salas

Story: My husband and I were 30 with three children under the age of 6 when we adopted a 16-year-old from foster care. Days were spent trying to be cool and strict and look like we knew what we were doing. Sleepless nights were spent recounting the dayâs failures. But every morning we got up and did it again. Made mistakes. Laughed. Cried. Argued. Apologized. Prayed. Reminded Brandan to wear his retainer. Cheered for him at football games. Cut his hair in the garage. And, somewhere in the mundane, I became Brandanâs mother. And Brandan became my son. â Denise Kendrick
Author: Denise Kendrick

Story: In my 40s, I spent summers with my widowed mother in England. Before returning to New York, I would write playful notes and hide them around her house. Under the silver candlestick, she discovered: âThe butcher, the baker and the candlestick maker â and your daughter â love you.â For weeks after I left, she would call and laugh. âI found another one of your little notes!â Cleaning out her house after she died, I found a box in her bedroom. Inside was every note Iâd given her, organized by year â a gift she gave back to me. â Jennifer Fell Hayes
Author: Jennifer Fell Hayes

Story: Tito asked me to marry him, but not for the happily ever after. He had AIDS â a death sentence in the early 1980s. He wanted his property to go to his partner, Michael, but his father disapproved. After Titoâs death, I was to wait a few years, then sign everything over to Michael. I was honored by Titoâs trust and might have said yes, but his father relented, allowing Michael to inherit Titoâs assets, though he would not be invited to the funeral. Forty years later, I miss my friend. Would he be married to Michael if he were alive? â Lynn Tamayo
Author: Lynn Tamayo

Story: âWhy canât you find someone?â my parents asked when I was 26. âHeâs not here yet,â I said. âHeâs in Africa.â (Iâve always been slightly psychic; my parents have always been slightly skeptical.) As the âDating Divaâ at Manhattanâs Learning Annex, I felt confident in my ability to help myself and others âfind a mate or just a date.â In my 40s, I still felt confident but relied less on my âdating tricks.â One rainy night, I bumped into a tall man who rolled his Râs. Today, my South African husband says he loves me and our daughter in Afrikaans. â Estelle Erasmus
Author: Estelle Erasmus

Story: We started dating a few months before the pandemic. She lived in New Jersey while I lived in New York, and she drove a dusty compact car. The back seat was like an Army surplus store: blankets, picnic chairs, snacks, water. She was a civil engineer and liked to be prepared. The first time we kissed was in her car, contorted across the front seats. I remember the scent of her shampoo, and the weight of everything behind us and the year ahead. The last message I received from her was: âThe pressure is too high, I canât. Iâm sorry.â â Rahul DâSilva
Author: Rahul DâSilva

Story: I started cleaning our apartment so I could take photos to remember it by. My husband was retiring, and we were moving from New York â leaving the place where two lonesome apartments combined into this one; where two single people combined as a pair; where I, at 63, had lived longest. What I really wanted was to remember our home in all its chaotic glory: open sardine tins, piles of papers and books. So I stopped tidying. Youâd think this mess was caused by moving, but really it was created because we were living. â Jill Lipton
Author: Jill Lipton

Story: Unlike the other trees Nanima planted at our home in Pakistan, I dislike this mango tree. Mango trees mean mango bugs. Three years ago, one of the mango treeâs branches touched my bedroom balcony, allowing bugs to infest my space. âThose bugs, they petrify me!â I said. (Although an adult, I was a baby in front of Nanima.) The next morning, she cut her beloved treeâs branch. Only a grandmother can love like that. This is my first spring without her. The tree will blossom, the bugs will come, but I wonât have Nanima to hear and appease my fears. â Rasti Iqbal Jamil
Author: Rasti Iqbal Jamil

Story: After four years of texting, we were finally going to meet. My father had died. On my way to my family in Venezuela, I stopped in Colombia, where my online lover lived. He had me at my most vulnerable. For three days, we loved intensely, making promises about marriage, dreaming of canary-yellow diamond rings. I left for work. Our dreams sustained me. Then we broke, and I broke too. My only satisfaction is the Pablo Neruda poem I left in his room. It reads: âCuantas veces, amor, te soÃ±Ã© sin verte?â How many times, love, did I dream of you without seeing you? â Sebastian Cabrices
Author: Sebastian Cabrices

Story: In 2017, my friend since 1979 had spinal surgery. I stole time from my vigil to purchase a hospital coffee. Distracted, I left my purse behind, and it was stolen. Security insisted my wallet â with driverâs license, personal information and family pictures â would turn up. It did not. Weeks later, an envelope arrived at my former office at the University of Wyoming. Return address? None. Just: âFound Scattered on Street.â Contents: faculty ID, library card, a nearly empty gum packet, one strangerâs kindness and the warmth I feel for someone I have never met. â Pamela Galbreath
Author: Pamela Galbreath

Story: On my fatherâs workdays, he would wait for me to wake. I would dress quickly, splashing water on my face. Leaving his scooter behind so we could talk along the way, he would speak of life, of love, both of us laughing; sometimes I would cry. âYouâll understand someday,â he would say when I searched his eyes for answers. A hug, then he would cross the busy street in Mombasa, Kenya. A smile in his eyes, he would stand on the other side and wave. I cherish this memory now that he has crossed over to lifeâs other side. â Derrick Ochieng
Author: Derrick Ochieng

Story: There are two countries with an âXâ in their English names. John is a Luxembourger; I am Mexican. Born in countries with different cultures and climates, we have two distinct ways of seeing our world. Yet older love is special because life has already shown you who you are and how others have been shaped in ways you canât always understand. I try to impress John with my high-school French. He tries to remember his high-school Spanish. We met after marriages, children and lives far from each other. But now we have marked each otherâs hearts with an âX.â â Alejandra Garza
Author: Alejandra Garza

Story: Last month, the emergency room doctor sat on the edge of my bed and said, âI have three children. Do you know how many times Iâve been pregnant?â I shook my head. âNine.â As she left, she added, âYou will have a boy and a girl. Iâve been right about my last seven friends!â The tears came and I gasped for air. Ten months of trying had ended in unthinkable loss. My husband gently cupped my face and said, âAll we have to do right now is breathe. Isnât that a wonderful thing?â And with our foreheads together, we did just that. â Beth Kuhn Metzler
Author: Beth Kuhn Metzler

Story: My family of four lives in San Francisco. In February, we had one of our first outings for pleasure since the pandemic began. At a stationery shop on Union Street, I was looking at greeting cards when Xavier, my 6-year-old, spontaneously declared, âI love you, Mommy.â The two store clerks at the counter paused what they were doing, then smiled as if embarrassed to be caught witnessing an intimate expression. To break the ice, I asked them, âArenât I so lucky?â Officially invited into our moment, they gladly agreed. â Debbie Dang
Author: Debbie Dang

Story: My boss at the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS wanted me to meet Susan. He said that she, a hardworking designer, needed to get out more. Imagining that meant âcouldnât get a date,â I felt more resigned than happy. âHow will I know you?â she asked over the phone. âIâll be the 5-foot-9 woman who looks like Iâm looking for someone.â She replied, âIâll be the 6-footer looking for you.â Susan entered the Noho Star, now permanently closed, in a cloud of colorful fabric. I was agog, thinking, âIâm not introducing her to anyone.â Iâm still agog. â Rosemary Kuropat
Author: Rosemary Kuropat

Story: Wonder Womanâs eyes on my ninth grade journal elicit sharp memories. I purchased the notebook when I was 14, a new student in a new state. Hounded by an internal villain wielding a whip of self-doubt, I tried to emulate Wonder Womanâs strength. The pages describe a young dancer fearful of being âan ugly, stumbling little snowflake who you could miss in a blink.â Now, at 18, I look at the trees unfurling after a long New Hampshire winter. Though I have learned to appreciate snow, I am always grateful when it melts. And this is a story about spring. â Victoria Chen
Author: Victoria Chen

Story: Our terms of endearment have always evolved. Once, after a movie, âdearâ and âdarlingâ morphed into âdearling.â During lockdown in Prague, the evolution accelerated: âDarlingâ became âDar-Dar,â then âDar,â followed by âNar-Darâ and âNar,â and finally âNar-Nar.â Meanwhile, âDearlingâ transformed into âDearlingest,â then âEst,â then âEst-est-est.â It makes sense: Working from home for a year and stuck in a second lockdown as the Czech Republic battles one of the worldâs highest Covid death rates, weâve had far more time together than usual. I just wonder: In what other ways has humanity evolved faster than usual this year? â Melody Rose McClure
Author: Melody Rose McClure

Story: Recently we toasted with champagne in your newly purchased East London flat. Three years earlier, I watched your red nails scratch thin hospital sheets, brought you cans of Coca-Cola and coloring books after you tried to overdose. I have never been so relieved about a friendâs failure. Friendships hold uncountable sorrows and joys, like toasting your new life or eating Ikea hot dogs in the store parking lot, our masks blowing like flags from our wrists. â Xan Pedisich
Author: Xan Pedisich

Story: âWhy is this night different from all the others?â Last Passover, there were more ways than usual. My father was hospitalized with low oxygen. My mother and sister, also sick, spent the holiday clutching their phones in case he called. I was with my partner, crying over chicken broth, gripped by fear. This year, I remember the virus that passed over my own blood, sparing my father as the Israelites were spared from the final plague. I find new meaning in âDayenu,â a Seder song of gratitude with the refrain: âIt would have been enough.â My familyâs health will always be enough. â Amanda Glickman
Author: Amanda Glickman

Story: Midway through 2020, I started planting seeds in my backyard. My daughter said, âYouâve wanted to do this for years. Do you like it?â âYes,â I said. âI love it.â At the time, I didnât realize I was growing more than tomatoes. Realizing old seeds are no longer growing is harder. â Karen Amster-Young
Author: Karen Amster-Young

Story: Grief was that relative I heard stories about. I knew her in the way I knew Uncle Gerald, someone I never met but learned so much about. Then my husband died, and there Grief was, shaking my hand. I offered her the guest bedroom, scrambling to make it comfortable, but not too comfortable because I didnât want her to stay long. Instead of the guest bedroom, she marched right into my bedroom and dropped her heavy bags. Years later, sheâs still with me, now an old friend, someone to sip martinis with and remember. â Barbara Phillips
Author: Barbara Phillips

Story: In March 2009, two weeks after my students voted me teacher of the year, I learned I wouldnât be returning to school after summer break. They surprised me, arriving at school wearing custom T-shirts that read âI support Ms. Minsky.â That expression of affection helped carry me through a dark time. â Connie Minsky
Author: Connie Minsky

Story: My first semester of college, I only called my mother twice. At my house, I felt generally misunderstood and judged for my weight; at school, I was finally free. But the pandemic forced me home. I spent the first months in my room. Then, my mother and I started watching Chinese competition shows together, bonding over the contestants. Now I make sure sheâs eating even when she avoids meals to stay thin. We converse in simple Mandarin, a language I hadnât bothered to learn before. I buy her flowers and cry when I think of leaving her. â Annabelle Wang
Author: Annabelle Wang

Story: I take a lot of photos. My house is filled with images of places I have visited and people I love. I rotate the photos, taking new ones, making more prints, slipping new pictures over old ones in frames. But I have realized, six months after my partnerâs sudden death, that the photos I have of John are all I will ever have. So I conjure up memories of him â hiking in the Sierras, enjoying a party, reading at the kitchen table. Love endures without fresh photos, but oh how I miss stealthily snapping him. â Ellen Greenblatt
Author: Ellen Greenblatt

Story Name: Lean on Me (When Youâre in Heels)
Story: Our pace slowed as Monicaâs feet started to hurt in her blue velvet heels. I was wearing sneakers and offered to switch. I stumbled along, leaning most of my weight on her shoulders. We only made it one city block before switching back. This wasnât the first or last time she would prop me up as I floundered uncomfortable in femininity. Later she would help me change my legal name and gender marker. She still loves â and can rock â high heels. But next time the night gets long, I will probably offer a piggyback ride. â Nat Mulkey
Author: Nat Mulkey

Story: From the back seat, my 5-year-old son, Jack, said: âMommy, why donât you have a boyfriend?â Freshly divorced and unsure how to answer, I asked why he asked. Jack replied, âBecause youâre really nice. You should be with someone nice.â I realized the troubles of my previous marriage had not gone unnoticed. Jack said I should look for someone kind, respectful and of medium height â like Grandma. Eight years later, Jack calls my husband, Greg, âDad.â I tease Greg that itâs a good thing that heâs on the shorter side, just like my mother. â Clara Koschnitzke Hoffmann
Author: Clara Koschnitzke Hoffmann

Story Name: I Guess I Passed Her Test
Story: As a dutiful girlfriend, I accompanied Arturo to J.F.K. Airport to pick up his sister, who was arriving from Buenos Aires. Greeting her, I casually asked what brought her to New York. âMami sent me to check you out,â she said. Years later, Mami was visiting us. Her reply? âPlease do, because you are everything I hoped for in a wife for my son.â How could I refuse? â Phyllis Meyers
Author: Phyllis Meyers

Story: In February 2019, my youngest sister, Melina, admitted herself into the hospital for PTSD from childhood trauma. When she returned home, she texted, âDo not contact me ever again!â Determined to get through to her, I invited her to walk with me and Preston, my goldendoodle. She loved Preston but refused. In March, Melina died of suicide. On a walk the morning after her funeral, Preston suddenly turned and barked behind us. Nothing was in sight. I felt then that Melina had changed her mind and decided, after all, to join us. â Sarina Tomel
Author: Sarina Tomel

Story: I spoke to Sun Ung in broken Chinese, excited hand gestures and hugs. We lived together for 18 years: a strong-willed Cambodian refugee and me, his spunky Texan granddaughter. Then his Alzheimerâs took hold. He would scrunch his eyebrows, searching for our history in a sea of fading memories. I started every sentence with, âRemember when â ?â But, one of our final nights together before he died last March, we sat beside each other in silence. A granddaughter without the words to convey her love. A grandfather who didnât need to remember the past to know she loved him anyway. â Sabrina Wong
Author: Sabrina Wong

Story: Chantal and I met in Bordeaux, France. I was an American student, with long hair and a beard, dressed like John Lennon in olive Army surplus fatigues. Chantal, whose grandfather escaped Mussolini, looked like Isabella Rossellini. We married in Oakland, Calif. Chantal did not want children; I did. We divorced. Chantalâs journey continued, wild as ever. Mine: law school, suburbs, remarriage, children and Little League. Chantal would sometimes call. She became a psychologist. Once, Chantal said she wanted a child and asked if Iâd be the father. I mistakenly told my wife. Flattered, remembering, hesitating, I said no. Nice though. â Mark Rice
Author: Mark Rice

Story: A blue dawn as I think about how life will proceed without 80-year-old me. How to make those dim vapors disperse? Eggs, coffee, a thin slice of toast and â dare I open a jar of my homemade marmalade? With the inordinate work to make the jam â slicing countless sour oranges into small pieces â Iâve always saved these jars to give to special people. But today, in a wild, life-affirming gesture, I open the preserves for myself. Sticky and runny, the marmalade acts as an elixir, melting away the trailing wisps of blue. â Marilyn Slutzky Zucker
Author: Marilyn Slutzky Zucker

Story: I was teaching English in Myanmar when we met, two years ago. Music connected us â afternoons strumming a cheap guitar as we tried to harmonize. I was learning Burmese. He covered our apartment in Post-it notes with each itemâs Burmese name. This January, I returned home to Australia because my mother was sick. In February, when the military staged a coup in Myanmar, he said, âThey stole our future.â I could feel his frustration and pain. But every night when we FaceTime, he smiles and joins his neighbors as they bang kitchenware in protest. A hopeful harmony. â Audric Co
Author: Audric Co

Story: For three days, Chris commuted six hours round trip from Virginia to his work in Pennsylvania so he could hold me as I mourned my father. Over the years, my father had done crazy drives for me, his steadfast help showing an unconditional love. Moving me from Virginia to Chicago, we talked so much we missed our exits. I thought the only people who would continue to love me that deeply were my mother and brother. But Chris did, and does. My father would be happy to know someone is still doing crazy drives for me. â Apurva Sisodia
Author: Apurva Sisodia

Story: The subway roared into 14th Street. His hand was tucked in my pocket; mine held yellow tulips. It was a brisk March evening, but the tulips were sunny, his hand warm, and I felt like spring. Wrapped in the comfort of a full belly and heart, squished into subway seats, I talked to him about things I canât remember now. âI had to take a picture,â a woman across the train said, waving her phone. âThe way youâre looking at each other â I have chills.â I miss that woman, the people she photographed and the steadiness of those springtime flowers. â Kaitlyn Powers
Author: Kaitlyn Powers

Story: My first message to you, 44 years after high school: âI remember you; you had that long, pretty hair.â You told me about the car accident that left your lower body paralyzed. I told you that our wholeness doesnât depend on the body. You wrote to me about making art, cooking, living in Mexico, your love for your son, your joyful creativity after surgery. In December, you stopped messaging. I was heartbroken to learn that you died. Then I reread your last message, about how we are connected in unseen and mystical ways. What a gift, intimacy with you. â Alice Hogan
Author: Alice Hogan

Story: After my 13-year marriage fell apart, I rented an apartment a few blocks from our family home in Rome. Three days later, Italy went into lockdown. I began a new life, along with the rest of the nation, working remotely and spending time with my children. My split was suddenly the second most important thing happening. As my wife and I grappled with the pandemic, pain and regret fell to the side. Is it possible that lockdown is our friend? It may seem cruel, but we are not ready for real life. â Federico Petrangeli
Author: Federico Petrangeli

Story: My grandmother Ruth was like a secret agent. Before cellphones or the internet, she would covertly track her grandchildren. At 23, I moved to Mexico to work for a resort. I was, at last, on my own. One night, while I was drinking with my co-workers at a beach bar, a man from a nearby village walked in and shouted my full name. When I responded, he marched up to me and said, âYour abuela has called each house in our village. I was chosen to find you with this message: âGram loves you. Please call.ââ â Amy Gotliffe
Author: Amy Gotliffe

Story: âItâs time, itâs time, for green ginger wine,â we would chant every Friday night as we danced around the kitchen, my loverâs hand at my waist, my arm around his wife. We drank wine from goblets as their toddler yelled happily at our feet. It would be a long time before I admitted to myself that sex with him no longer felt right, that I was more in love with our life together than I was with my lover. When I broke up with him, I stayed friends with his wife, and wondered if their child would remember me. â Melanie Pryor
Author: Melanie Pryor

Story: Outside the Chicago airport the cold creeps up my coat, stiffening my spine as I hug my husband. We havenât been apart for over a year. I board the plane alone because Nick isnât vaccinated. At immigration in Harare, I remove my wedding ring and check the âsingleâ box. Love between two men is illegal in Zimbabwe. I adapt to survive. When I emerge, the balmy air relaxes my spine as I hug my mother, Bharati. We cry, mourning the togetherness weâve lost this year. I also cry for my husband, who drove home alone. One reunion requiring another separation. â Khameer Kidia
Author: Khameer Kidia

Story: During World War II, Lucy was sent out of Germany by her family. Theo was imprisoned in a concentration camp until the end of the war. In 1959, they lived a floor below us in our Bronx apartment building. They had a piano but no children. My parents had three girls but no piano. When Lucy and Theo found out that the nuns at our Catholic school offered cheap piano lessons, they insisted that we practice in their apartment. Theo would sometimes play show tunes while we danced and sang along. Such a joyful cacophony we created! I hear our music still. â Rosemary Colangelo Stewart
Author: Rosemary Colangelo Stewart

Story: Marjorie, my wife of 41 years, a member of our community fire department in Santa Fe, had a severe bleeding stroke. Leaving the hospital, I drove home through a raging snowstorm, fearing that I might get in an accident and be unable to help her. At home, I cried in our bed. Our cat, Bunnie, came in. Waking in the morning, I discovered that Bunnie had gathered six of her toys from around the house and placed them by my bed. After Marjorie died, my âfeline social workerâ looked after me until she was 20. â Bob Mizerak
Author: Bob Mizerak

Story: My childhood memories of the Chinese New Year include the noise of my grandmotherâs mahjong tiles click-clacking together. When my grandmother, Yuan, moved away from our hometown in Inner Mongolia to join my parents in the big city of Shanghai, she lost contact with her mahjong friends. My parents arenât enthusiastic about the game, so my cousin and I offered to learn and play with our grandmother. We were naturally gifted, winning round after round. Or so I thought, until I better understood the game: My grandmother had all the tiles, but she was letting us win. â Ke Ran Huang
Author: Ke Ran Huang

Story: I woke to Nkoziâs arm around my waist. âI had another money dream,â she said, her brow furrowing. We were barely scraping by that year. Nkozi had a lot of money dreams. âWanna borrow my dream?â I asked. She answered in a formless hum. I pressed my lips to her temple and told her about quahogging on the beach where I grew up: digging in the sand for the quahogs, scrubbing their shells until they looked like bone, enjoying fritters and chowder. I whispered until her brow was smooth and her head was heavy in the crook of my arm. â Serena Libardi
Author: Serena Libardi

Story: After witnessing my parentsâ divorce, I swore my life would be different. When I got divorced in my late 30s, I saw a psychologist to deal with the guilt of leaving my workaholic attorney husband and potentially hurting our children. âWhat will you miss if you leave him?â she said. âSitting at a dinner table, having meals together,â I said. âBut, how can you miss what youâve never had?â I felt a gut punch; weâd rarely shared family meals. âIs that what you missed as a child?â âYes,â I replied, finally letting myself mourn my past and present. â Kerrie Houston Reightley
Author: Kerrie Houston Reightley

Story: Sometimes the mind slips into dark places. On one such day, I was in the kitchen when my mind busied itself thinking about all I hadnât achieved. Juggling a career and motherhood, I wished I had more time for both. Believing myself to be alone, I muttered, âWhat am I good at?â Behind me, quite unexpectedly and matter-of-factly, without a momentâs hesitation, my 6-year-old piped up in his precocious way. âBut Mom, without you there would be no laughter.â Nate is almost 33 now, living on the opposite coast. Thankfully, laughter still lights our way on dark days. â Nancy Rae
Author: Nancy Rae

Story: In the early 1970s, as a college freshman in Iowa, I met a guy who was only interested in me as a friend. We played pinball (he liked the way I leaned into the flippers) and watched movies. David wasnât much of a cook (he used a shoe box as a dish drainer) so I was surprised when he invited me for dinner on Valentineâs Day, presenting me with grilled chicken livers (my unconventional favorite) cut into the shape of hearts. Our own hearts are now filled with scars, stents and pacemakers, but also 48 years of love. â Bonnie Miller Rubin
Author: Bonnie Miller Rubin

Story: On our fourth date, Tayo and I ate tacos on the steps of a colorful church in Oakland, Calif. A white-haired man shuffling down the street shouted at us with slurred speech and apparent admiration: âLook at you two! Are you in love?â Tayo smiled and said, âSure.â The old man, either unsatisfied or unable to hear, belted out again, âWhatâs that? Are you two in love?â Tayo and I looked at each other and laughed. We shouted a resounding âYes!â The old man seemed appeased, and we felt the first glimmer of our answerâs truth. â Theda Maritzer
Author: Theda Maritzer

Story Name: Welcome to âOur Weird Little Worldâ
Story: When my oldest friend got pregnant, I felt embarrassingly abandoned. Since fourth grade, Eloise and I had been cocooned in our weird little world; while excited, I worried that our friendship would soon become a faint star in the constellation of her life. I imagine that others in my position would feel similarly, yet I judged myself for not being more exuberant. Eloiseâs daughter came, grew and learned to crawl. One day, on FaceTime, as I watched her wiggle through the doggy door, I realized I couldnât be jealous. She was a little weirdo, just like us. â Cat Coyne
Author: Cat Coyne

Story: People call me heartless. Iâm not. I lack one type of human connection, not all of them. I may never have a girlfriend or boyfriend, but I can love family, friends and pets. People say they can âfixâ me; they canât. Iâm not broken, just different. People say itâs made up. It isnât. Iâm not heartless. Iâm not broken, not a liar and not loveless. Iâm just me, and Iâm asexual. â Noa Callie
Author: Noa Callie

Story: After Hazel and I got married at the ages of 20 and 21, I questioned our judgment in choosing to marry so young. When we had a baby soon after, I wondered how I could possibly support a family. In our mid-40s, I thought we were too young to become grandparents, though our grandchildren are lovely. Then when Hazel passed away at 50 from the coronavirus, I finally realized why we got married so young: We werenât meant to grow old together. And I am grateful for our time. â Sean Luke Dado
Author: Sean Luke Dado

Story: I found myself in rural Oregon, two years into a marriage with the wrong man and on a steep learning curve. My home: a drafty hand-built cabin with an inefficient wood stove. My partner: a developing opioid addict. Life was dark and cold. Then I met my neighbors. Some my age, some 50 years older. They shared wine, stories and laughter. They taught me to identify native plants, dress a turkey, read the lay of the land, preserve a garden harvest. And to mend everything worth saving and loving â which, their kindness taught me, included myself. â Cate Keller
Author: Cate Keller

Story: Amy was a spunky 8-year-old. She lived with our friends, but they were too old to care for her, so she would soon move to another foster home. I was no oneâs idea of maternal and had never thought of raising children. But Amy wanted a family. I told my wife, âI want to adopt Amy.â We filled out paperwork, readied a bedroom and waited. After a judgeâs OK, we loaded Amyâs clothes, crayons and copies of Harry Potter into our SUV. Itâs been 17 years. Iâm still no oneâs idea of maternal, but Iâm lucky to be Amyâs mother. â Lynn Domina
Author: Lynn Domina

Story: The first notable thing was that his Chinese name, Du Dao Na, sounded like, âDude, where are you going?â The second: He had the nicest toes. Weâd met as graduate-level exchange students in Taiwan. Don was wearing sandals. At Christmas, he surprised me with a kiss. I hesitated. He said, âItâs OK â Iâm not dating until I find the one Iâll marry.â I asked, âHow do you know thatâs not me?â He replied, âI worry youâd tire of me.â I said, âOh yeah? I bet I wonât!â Twenty-five years, three countries and two children later, Iâm still winning that bet. â Doris Chou-Durfee
Author: Doris Chou-Durfee

Story: My father lay dying of the coronavirus. A normally ebullient 96-year-old, he drifted in and out of consciousness as I, also infected, sat at his bedside. His lucid moments were precious opportunities for connection and FaceTime calls with his grandchildren. One afternoon, he commanded me to get his yellow collared shirt, blue blazer, khaki pants, Sperry shoes and one of his many bow ties. I laid everything on his bed as he talked about going out to a lovely dinner with my mother, who had died 17 years earlier. Then my father closed his eyes. â Katharine Cunningham
Author: Katharine Cunningham

Story: My grandparents had a 20-foot-long, âBreaking Badâ-style camper that they would drive from snowy Wisconsin to sunny Florida. When I told my grandfather about my pipe dream to take the van on a graduation road trip, he smiled and said, âIâll drive.â By the time I graduated college, both the camper and my grandpa were gone. Instead, I drove all over the East Coast in his â99 Toyota â his sunglasses and spare change still in the cup holders. As I started my journey, I gripped the weathered steering wheel and smiled. It felt like he and I were driving. â Angie Newman
Author: Angie Newman

Story: We took a course at Barnard about the birds of New York. Before a quiz, I made a GarageBand track with bird names and Audubon recordings. âBlue jay.â âTufted titmouse.â I wrote, then rewrote, an email to Lhana: âIn case this helps you study for the quiz!â She didnât respond. But after we took the quiz on a windy day in Jamaica Bay, she sat next to me on the bus to Manhattan and said thanks. Years later, I proposed to her while playing the bird songs over speakers in an empty theater. When she said yes, my heart soared. â Madeline Taylor
Author: Madeline Taylor

Story: I last saw Ajay on our two-year anniversary; it will be our third before I see him next. During the pandemic, I have forgotten what itâs like to be with him in real life. Some nights, I ask him to stay with me until morning. I place my phone next to my pillow as if heâs there next to me and listen to him shuffle against the blankets. Then, I close my eyes and fill in the blanks: his arms looped around me, my legs braided gently into his. It reminds my body of the warmth it has forgotten. â Katherine Hu
Author: Katherine Hu

Story Name: Shelter Dog for a Sheltered Heart
Story: They deemed her unadoptable because she was scared of everything. But lying on the cold shelter floor that January day, she cracked open my guarded heart. A week later, I brought home my shaggy little bear and called her Stevie. Sheâs still scared of many things: the garbage truck, men in uniform, loud children. But she has developed a fondness for just as many others: barbecue chicken, snuggles on the couch, walks in the park. If you want to learn how to be loved, adopt a dog who needs to learn how, too. â Lee Propp
Author: Lee Propp

Story: Mario was a foster child; I was a sheltered bookworm. We married young in Union, Maine. When the seven-year itch hit, we decided to renovate a cliff-side villa in Santorini for a crazy Malibu defense attorney. It was 1994, before the islandâs spine sprouted resorts. Work days included transporting bags of cement on donkeysâ backs. Days off we hiked, swam, tanned on topless beaches. We toasted our relationship every pink Homeric sunset. At night, we ate fava beans and fish washed down with retsina. And olives. Oh, those olives. â Sherry Barker Abaldo
Author: Sherry Barker Abaldo

Story: Years ago, I was in Wisconsin visiting Mom. One night, slightly âintoxicated, my brother laid into her and me with hatred of the president she and I supported. Stunned, we left. Politics have divided our houses since. Mom called one recent night: My brother has coronavirus. Shaken, I debated reaching out. Would he want to hear from me? Next morning, I heard about a congressman whose son had died by suicide and the support he received from Democrats and Republicans during the insurrection in Washington. I texted my brother and his wife with inquiries, well wishes. Only his wife replied. â Wendy Lukomski
Author: Wendy Lukomski

Story: I saw Anthony now and then in Los Angeles bars. We were always friendly. Then, one Friday we bumped into each other at a street fair. We ran into each other again on Saturday. Sunday, too. Still, only flirty chat and ambivalence. On Monday, while I was driving, Anthony walked right past me. I finally gave him my number and cooked him dinner a week later. Still married 17 years later, we donât believe in âmeant to be.â We believe in a mixture of heart and head: luck and commitment. â Dean Decent
Author: Dean Decent

Story: The day before my 32nd birthday, Greg gripped my hand in the emergency room. The sonogram revealed a miscarriage. He comforted and anchored me as I waded in a sea of grief for weeks, then months. Seven years and two children later, Greg remembered to pick up my 39th birthday cake, along with hand sanitizer, as New York City lurched toward a grim shutdown. Now, almost a year later, almost a year older, almost a year at home, I walk bravely toward my 40th birthday, knowing the true milestone is our love and health. â Christine Byun
Author: Christine Byun

Story: She took my picture at New Yorkâs Village Halloween Parade. I walked to our first date feeling intimidated by her beauty and photography credentials. I texted, âHow about we donât speak tonight?â She replied, âSounds fun! For how long?â âUntil it hurts.â We went to Eataly. Strangers helped us order, thinking we were deaf. After a kiss and a jazz club, I finally spoke: âWhere are we going?â She pointed at me. We went to my apartment and lived happily together for the next eight months, until she moved to Europe for work. Now thereâs too much silence. â Steve Wruble
Author: Steve Wruble

Story: Chenoa was born six days before I turned 2. Growing up, we had joint birthday parties and were mistaken for twins. I fought for individuality, resisting when our mother tried to dress us alike. Chenoa cried when I escaped our shared bottom bunk for my own bed, or hid from her in the Delaware woods near our home to read in precious solitude. She followed me to college, then D.C. We lived together as sister-soulmate-besties until romance pulled her to Philadelphia. Now I cherish our rare, precious visits, whispering and giggling in my bed like neither of us ever left. â Candace Valencia Freeman
Author: Candace Valencia Freeman

Story: Standing near her locker in a Bronx high school, my 16-year-old mother was stood up by a boy who, she later learned, was with another girl on the field bleachers. My father swept in, offering to walk her home and carry her books. For the next 71 years, they would carry one another until they both became Covid-19 casualties, dying 10 hours and one mile apart in different hospitals. Their funeral was a blend of six feet under meets six feet apart. The only solace was that they would rest together â always, as their favorite Frank Sinatra song declared. â Marcy Tolkoff Levy
Author: Marcy Tolkoff Levy

Story: In our mid-30s, Angie and I got together, both of us wanting a baby. On a date at my nephewâs high school musical, one child sang loudly off tune, danced in the wrong direction and dropped lines. As others covered for him, I leaned over and whispered, âWhat would you do if that was your kid?â Angie looked at him, then me, and replied, âIâd just love him so much.â Now that we have two 13-year-olds, her words echo a deep truth about parenting: Youâll love your children no matter what, but when itâs tough, love them more. â Elizabeth Stark
Author: Elizabeth Stark

Story Name: A Warm Cup in Our Camper
Story: He brings me coffee in bed every morning. Itâs far from the dreamy depiction of romantic comedies â not in an apartment with a city view or a house tucked in a cul-de-sac, but in the frigid cold of our tiny camper, where I sit, barely awake, swimming in a sea of blankets. We live in a camper in the Kentucky woods to keep from being homeless. For me, he wakes early to make coffee in an old-fashioned teakettle on the fire outside. I sip it, knowing how loved and lucky I am. â Amanda Jean Alley
Author: Amanda Jean Alley

Story: Twenty-nine years ago, my mother upstaged Jesus by dying right before Christmas. I was a single mother of a 4-year-old. I made the season merry for my daughter, though inside I felt like the sun would never shine. Over the years, I accepted that sadness would arrive around December. I greeted it at the door with a cocktail in hand â recently, with a pot of coffee. Sad and happy memories will always sit together at my holiday table, like restless houseguests. In the new year, happiness extends its stay while sadness slips quietly out the door. â Gloria Barone Rosanio
Author: Gloria Barone Rosanio

Story: Two weeks before moving to Maine from Boston, Annabelle was trying to find âLSTD,â what she calls a âlittle something to do.â I was trying to figure out how to date for the first time since transitioning. It was supposed to be a fling. But our first date lasted six hours. Our second lasted 12. For our fourth date, Anabelle drove down from Maine just to see me for 48 hours. Three years later, we live together in Portland where we had our fifth date. With luck, a âlittle something to doâ might become the rest of our lives. â Elliot Walsh
Author: Elliot Walsh

Story: When my son was small, we turned our âlove youâ affirmations at bedtime into a game; the winner made the other feel most loved. One night, I told him that I loved him so much, my love filled his bedroom and flowed out the windows like a tidal wave into the streets of New York City. Not to be outdone, 6-year-old Quinn said he loved me so much that his love filled every single atom in the entire universe, and there was nowhere I could go where I wouldnât feel it and know it. He won. â Laura Plybon
Author: Laura Plybon

Story Name: Back in the Rhythm of Conversation
Story: My 14-year-old, Vedant, dwells in a dungeon (i.e. basement) under my bedroom. Through the muffled cadence of his voice, I deduce if heâs in virtual school or playing an online game. Thrice a day, he comes up for air, asking, âWhatâs there to eat?â We used to talk a lot on our car rides, about life and feelings. Now we have nowhere to go. For the holidays, I make him my sous chef. Slicing a butternut squash, my knife slips. He takes my bleeding finger in his hand and blows a kiss. Food an excuse, we talk about feelings again. â Yogyata Singh DavÃ©
Author: Yogyata Singh DavÃ©

Story: Because of the pandemic, John and I are thousands of miles apart and separated by borders that are indefinitely closed. On my weekend, he takes me on a trip to South Korea through Google Maps. We âstayâ at the beautiful Hotel Shilla, where the daily rate costs more than my weekly food budget. We go on Street View to see the school John grew up attending and visit his favorite childhood haunts. We travel to different cities, my cursor dragging through streets and alleyways. John says, âI hope I can take you there for real one day.â â Erika Lee
Author: Erika Lee

Story: Max and I first locked eyes across a classroom our sophomore year of high school, each sensing someone uncannily familiar staring back. We became fast friends, and suburban mischief ensued. We taught ourselves (and each other) a new, queer brand of masculinity, reveling in the freedom that comes from an instinctive mutual understanding. Then high school ended. She left for the military. I, for university. Differences that once felt small and sparse grew vast and plentiful. Yet, as weâve come into our own, our paths realigned. Sometimes, it still feels like that first meeting, like looking into a mirror. â Kelsey Smoot
Author: Kelsey Smoot

Story: On Jan. 3, in the emergency room with a broken femur, I realized my year had ended before it began. I had fallen 20 feet in a climbing accident in a gym in Atlanta. My hospital room was filled with my family, my partner, and fruit freshly cut by my mother. âItâll heal,â said my surgeon. Twelve months, multiple quarantines and one healed femur later, I look 20 feet around me and still see my family, my partner and freshly cut fruit. I feel hopeful that next year will lead to further healing. â Melissa Zhu
Author: Melissa Zhu

Story: The first winter I saw snow was the first winter I fell in love. Iâve always adored the holidays, but growing up in Florida meant I never experienced the âWhite Christmasâ dream. After moving to Dallas, I started dating a woman who worked on a Christmas tree lot across the street from my apartment. Marleana would come over, smelling of pine, her arms toned from all the lifting. She was my lesbian Hallmark Christmas film fantasy. She even owned a shiny red truck that we drove in to find snow. Her Christmas gift this year? An engagement ring. â Hannah Melin
Author: Hannah Melin

Story: In Kolkata, âI love youâ is not said often, and certainly not to parents. It is considered over the top; translated into Bengali, it can sound mawkish. I improvise when I call my parents in India from my apartment in New York. âI wish I had your tenacity,â I tell my mother. I praise my fatherâs compassion. âWish you were hereâ is the furthest I venture. Yesterday, when my mother said that she longed to see me and her voice faltered, I blurted out those three words. The heart grows fonder when parents are old and away, but a pandemic makes it bolder. â Satarupa Ghosh Roy
Author: Satarupa Ghosh Roy

Story Name: âI Need to Get Over Someoneâ
Story: I walked into the cramped East Village candle store. The man behind the counter asked what I needed. âI heard that you â¦ help people,â I said. He rubbed his hands together like he was about to make his favorite meal. âI need to get over someone,â I said. He nodded and retrieved a black candle from a shelf: âI need your initials and his.â I watched as he carved my heartbreak into the wax. âBurn this for seven days. Youâll feel better.â On day seven, I met someone new. It was a brief, healing romance. I never looked back. â Felice Neals
Author: help

Story: âWho is that woman?â my father asks me, pointing to a framed photo on the wall. âSheâs so beautiful it makes me cry.â The woman in the photo is my mother, Rosemary. They were married for 56 years before she passed away. They slept in the same bed until the end, holding hands every night as they drifted off to sleep. My father has Alzheimerâs. Some days he doesnât know who she is; others he speaks as if sheâs in the room, calling out over his shoulder, âRose â â as if memory is music only he can hear. â Amy Massingale
Author: Amy Massingale

Story: In 2017, on the way to our third family funeral in four weeks, our car died outside a Minnesota highway sex shop. I hopped around the parking lot to stay warm as my husband called the tow company. âWeâre trying to get to a funeral,â he said. âOur car died outside of â Pure Pleasure.â Heâs always resilient, but I worried about his spirits; this was another setback during a harsh year. His mother and stepmother texted, suggesting that his recently deceased father had pranked us. We smiled, joking about going inside the shop to âwarm up,â but the tow arrived. â Laura Logsdon
Author: Laura Logsdon

Story: It was Los Angeles in the 1950s, and my mother was ahead of her time. After my older sister, Debbie, got a doll, I wanted one just like hers. Of course my mother said yes. My motherâs friend, June, came over. They sat at the kitchen table. I was within earshot, dressing my beloved doll, when June said, âMarian, boys shouldnât play with dolls.â To which my mother responded, âIf Danny wants to play with dolls, he can play with dolls.â My doll was dressed and ready for an outing, and my mother looked at me adoringly. â Daniel Nathanson
Author: Daniel Nathanson

Story: Running to stay strong, to fill time, to be connected to ground and air and the space between one breath in and another out. Sometimes running is meditative solitude, sometimes joyful: for me, and me alone! Sometimes the isolation is crushing. Tears start before my feet stop. An evening run, 10 months into weathering the pandemic on my own. Another runner and I fall in step. Thereâs no explicit acknowledgment or agreement. But for a quarter mile in Queens, we maintain our pace. Breathing heavy through masks. Moving in tandem until our paths diverge. Distant but close. â Paige Arthur
Author: Paige Arthur

Story Name: No Need for the Awkward Talk
Story: On our first anniversary, my husband gave me a beautiful piece of raku pottery. I loved that pot with its iridescent glaze so much that he gave me another piece for my birthday. And another for Hanukkah. I thought about telling him that my pottery collection was complete. The next year he surprised me with a glass vase. I considered launching into the uncomfortable âI have enough breakable containersâ talk but held my tongue. Six months later, he wrapped up my vase and gave it to his relative. I didnât know whether to be angry or relieved. I chose relieved. â Ilene Haddad
Author: Ilene Haddad

Story: My mother, Wilma, adored Lifetime movies. Sick days away from school meant sleeping in, waking to the hum of television. Sporting an oversized T-shirt and fever, I would inch into the hall, listening for those sentimental melodramas. Iâd creep to the living room couch and burrow against my mother. Though I wasnât normally allowed to watch these films, my illness acted as a skeleton key. My mother stroked my forehead, covered my eyes from the wet, on-screen kisses. I listened to her laughs and gasps, learning when to laugh and gasp myself. I was her flu-ridden impersonator, her couch-bound copycat. â Ashley Jeffalone
Author: Ashley Jeffalone

Story Name: Two Equestrians Walk Into an Emergency Room
Story: We met in an emergency department north of Paris. After separate horse-riding accidents, we found ourselves there sporting ripped, muddy jodhpurs and fractured collarbones. The wait meant we could speak at length and realize that we agreed on nothing: politics, religion, philosophy, literature, equestrian ideology. We even clashed on the level of pain a broken collarbone caused. But we shared a fervent French belief in freedom of expression. Have our differences have softened over the years? No. Against the odds, we live, love, feud and laugh in rural France, surrounded by the horses that brought us together. â Fiona McGeachie Gallot
Author: Fiona McGeachie Gallot

Story: When my friends ask me over FaceTime how Iâm doing, I tell them that I spend a lot of time crying. Itâs easier than admitting that I canât seem to get out of bed before 2 p.m. Or wash the dishes that are stinking up my sink. Or get done any work that I normally love doing. But itâs more honest than âgood.â Sometimes they laugh and say âsame,â and sometimes they look down and donât know what to say. The rest of the conversation limps along. I apologize for being a stranger. They call me every week anyway. â Jemma Dooreleyers
Author: Jemma Dooreleyers

Story Name: A Breakup, a Bomb Threat and a Renewed Trust in Love
Story: We met during a bomb threat. I exited the D.C. metro to see yellow tape blocking my street. She asked me if I knew what happened. I said no. She asked me to dinner. With time to kill before I could enter my building, I said yes. She was blonde, Christian and a Red Sox fan: a Holy Trinity of forbidden fruit for me, son of New Yorkâs Upper West Side. (We also understood each otherâs jokes too late.) We werenât right for one another. But, after a previous breakup, she got me back out there. Bombs away.â Jay Rappaport
Author: Jay Rappaport

Story: A posh Westchester County girl and a poor Mississippi farm boy meet in Jiu-Jitsu class. At university, she studies operational meteorology; he studies English and writes poetry. It takes them only five months from first date to vows and embroidered towels. With tensions high during a Thanksgiving visit to her family with their infant son, her grandmother tells them that they are only together for the sex. Tears ensue. Bags are packed. Yet, after 17 years, two children and six jobs in Alaska and South Dakota, I have to say, dear reader, the sex is still spectacular. â Stan Wise
Author: Stan Wise

Story: My skin knew on our second date. It warned me that our connection was too quick, too intense with red, peeling patches across my cheeks and chin. (Dermatitis, dermatologists said, unsure of the trigger. Stress, maybe, or some unknown irritant. I dismissed it with prescription desoximetasone.) My skin knew the week before our wedding, swelling until my eyes shut tight, so puffy and pink and full of panic. My skin knew the moment it met my wedding band. The rash on my ring finger only left when I did, two years later. My skin always knew. Underneath, I did too. â Jessica DeFino
Author: Jessica DeFino

Story: In June, my 86-year-old father, Pete, had a stroke and broke his leg. By September, he was still in a wheelchair, hands unsteady. What to do for my mother Louiseâs 81st birthday? âI know,â he said to me. âShe wants a haircut. Iâll trim her hair.â Days later, I approached their porch, met by my redheaded mother and her new âdo. Punk cut. Sideburns. Half-inch bangs pointing forward like the bill of a cap. Without exchanging a word, we start laughing â guffawing, really. My mother shushes me once we can breathe. âMary, donât say anything to him. Donât hurt your daddyâs feelings.â â Mary Storms
Author: Mary Storms

Story Name: Two Kitchens, Halfway Across the World
Story: My American student visa was two weeks from expiring. I was preparing to return home to India, where I would stay until international travel restrictions lifted. My mother called, asking what I wanted to eat when I got to Mumbai. She would plan her lockdown shopping accordingly. âPani puri!â I answered. Later that day, I was chatting with my boyfriendâs mother while she washed dishes in her Pennsylvania kitchen. She asked, âIs there anything youâd like me to cook for you before you leave?â At that moment, I yearned for the two kitchens to be one. â Chaarvi Modi
Author: Chaarvi Modi

Story: After the funeral, I tidied the guest room for my mother, who was moving in temporarily while adjusting to life without my father. I was restless, believing I should have convinced him to see a doctor sooner. When I pulled a cloth along the closet shelf, a shower of mint Lifesavers rained down, left behind from my fatherâs last visit. An ex-smoker, he always kept his mouth busy. I unwrapped one, placing it, Communion-like, on my tongue. I wasnât able to save my fatherâs life; the lung cancer was a wildfire. But as the Lifesaver dissolved, it cleansed me. â Julia Bruce
Author: Julia Bruce

Story: Visiting my parents in Seattle, I expected my Tinder match with Jason to go like all the rest: warm hello, flirty banter, gradual trailing off. Back then, I traveled constantly for work, swiping everywhere, jaded but still looking despite myself. I returned home to Boston before Jason and I could meet. We communicated constantly. Discovering that neither of us had plans for Thanksgiving, we decided to meet somewhere between us (Nashville) and celebrate. We ate turkey and potatoes on our first date. One year married, Jason admits that he wasnât looking for anyone outside of a five-mile radius. â Ian McKinley
Author: Ian McKinley

Story: In 1998, I decided to get rid of my very 1980s-looking bachelor furniture. After posting on Craigslist, a gentleman came over with a tape measure. Everything would fit, including my king-size platform bed. He just needed run it by his girlfriend. The next day, the doorbell rang. When I opened the door, I saw the man and my ex-girlfriend from 20 years earlier. We shared our surprise, then moved on to the bedroom set. They said it was perfect. I said to my ex, âThat was ours â are you sure you want it?â âAbsolutely.â And off they went. â Paul Weinberg
Author: Paul Weinberg

Story: Two travel nurses, we arrived in New Mexico to help with the pandemic. We met in the hospitalâs Covid-19 tent, glimmers of desert sun streaming in. Pushing through 12-and-a-half-hour shifts, we interacted as we treated patients and tested the sick. A quiet connection grew. With our faces covered, we could only see each otherâs eyes. I didnât see his hidden smile for weeks. When I did, it felt like seeing weeks of masked smiles in an instant. His face, once unknown, soon became home. His heart, a remedy for uncertainty. â Jacqueline McMahon
Author: Jacqueline McMahon

Story: At 5, I believed that my father could perform magic. In Manilaâs moist heat, he drove in stop-and-go traffic with five screaming children and a broken AC. If we were very quiet, he said, he would use his powers to make the billboard flip screens. We quieted and he chanted an incantation, waved his hand, then flicked his fingers in perfect sync with the billboard change. Goosebumps peppered my arms. No one talked until I begged him to do it again. He died when I was 10. To this day, magic is intertwined with my memories of him.â Rowena Leong Singer
Author: Rowena Leong Singer

Story: Carlos rubs my feet and kisses my toes when we lie under the sun near the Hudson River. I like to watch him. It soothes me to know someone so gentle moves through this world and has chosen to move through it with me. When he laughs his eyes crinkle, and he covers his mouth because he thinks his teeth are a mess. I think his teeth are beautiful. When itâs cloudy, he tells me not to worry, his dance will wish away the rain. What he doesnât know is that it matters little â Carlos is the sun. â Madhuri Pavamani
Author: Madhuri Pavamani

Story: From a refugee camp in Uganda, my mother, Safiya, calls to ask how I am doing in Canada. She has been listening to the BBC and heard that the cost of living is climbing in North America. âPlease do not send me money until things get better for you,â she says. I am overcome with emotion, realizing that my aging mother, who fled civil war in Somalia, is more worried about me despite her vulnerabilities. As I navigate the pandemic, I am comforted by her love, which means so much more than the monthly 150 dollars I send her. â Muno Osman
Author: Muno Osman

Story: The polar vortex of 2019 arrived in Montana, bringing snow, snow, snow and paralyzing cold. A single mother and cattle rancher, I drove my boys 50 miles to school, returned to feed my 200 cattle midday, then retrieved the boys through blinding whiteouts and ice, ice, ice. No help available, I pushed through alone. My truck tire chains disappeared in snow, frigid cattle cried, the neighborâs newborn calves unable to survive. On Saturday, my 18-year-old son, Riley, saw my exhaustion. âIâll help you plow.â Four hours later at -10 degrees, he stepped off the tractor. The road was open.â Jenny Kahrl
Author: Jenny Kahrl

Story Name: Just Me and My Sea Monkeys
Story: I was in love and in lockdown in a small flat in Leith, Scotland. I had a lot of feelings and nowhere to put them. So I bought sea monkeys. I poured in the powder and checked the water temperature. For weeks, nothing. My last-ditch effort at finding something small (and within the rental agreement) to nurture was pointless. But then, so small you could barely make them out, a glimmer of hope and companionship in two tiny wriggling specks. â Claire Aubin
Author: Claire Aubin

Story: After dinner this March, my 28-year-old son decided to leave this world. He left me his cat. I didnât want his cat; I wanted him. His cat didnât want me; she wanted him. She cries all night. I cry all day. She sneaks into his bedroom to look for him; so do I. She smells his sheets; so do I. She waits by the front door; so do I. Weâve learned to find comfort in each other. We snuggle, sleep and mourn together. I had a beautiful boy named Elias. Now I have a beautiful cat named Damie. â Deirdre Stein
Author: Deirdre Stein

Story: Iâve received the same email twice within the past six months, a notification from LinkedIn that the man I had an affair with more than a decade ago viewed my profile. He was never good with the internet, so I doubt he realizes I can see this. Maybe it was his partner, on his account, communicating a deliberate: âI see you.â I donât know, but Iâm ashamed to admit that the messages made me feel much like he did years ago. Itâs still nice to be noticed. â Karen Moore
Author: Karen Moore

Story: They were the perfect pair â strikingly red, lustrous and cashmere-lined. I fell in love with my gloves, Lefty and Righty. However, like many ideal couples, they met an untimely separation one wintry day. I searched everywhere for Righty, mourning its loss. The remainder of the winter, as punishment, I wore a pair of cheap black gloves, ill-fitting and pilly. Fate intervened in the spring. Peeping under a mound of melting icy snow, faded, frozen and shriveled, was Righty! A chance encounter, saddle soap and love brought Lefty and Righty together, still the perfect pair. â Nancy M. Newman
Author: Nancy M. Newman

Story: In 1966, I saw Ken at New Havenâs only gay bar on Halloween. We ate hamburgers and then went back to his room at Yale, where we made out in front of his fireplace. I stepped on his glasses, then tried to hide that I had broken them by pushing them under a chair. I remember snuggling into him (he is a head taller than me) and feeling safe for the first time in my life. This Halloween marks 54 years together. I say it was love at first sight, even though Ken had trouble seeing me. âÂ Ronald Kirchem
Author: Ronald Kirchem

Story: âGot your passports? Underwear? Flashlight radios?â My family of five split into two cars, figuring a car saved was a car gained. Mid-dinner, âEvacuation Orderâ pinged on our phones. The inferno scorched the foothills, threatening our San Jose, Calif., home. We sped to a beachside inn, the waves our protector. Amid the hazy Pacific air, Dad â bereft of utensils â whomped a watermelon open. My sister, Arianna, humored spotty video classes. My mom and my brother, Aidan, dug a sand tunnel. Whether our house would survive was anyoneâs guess, but in this salty seaside suite, we found hearth and home. â Melody Cao
Author: Melody Cao

Story: We call ourselves the Smalls. Both under 5-foot-7, my boyfriend and I laugh about how different life must be with a few extra inches. On March 23, panic was mounting in New York City. When my mother called, we had barely figured out how to coexist in my studio apartment. My uncle â 68 years old and healthy â had died of coronavirus. Four hundred square feet isnât much space to grieve, but the walls never closed in. Seven months later, space remains limited and our size is unchanged. The loss is immeasurable, but so is the love. â Sophie Jacob
Author: Sophie Jacob

Story: Mrs. Abby played guitar. She was young and beautiful, and I loved her so. She let me stay in at recess even though that was her break time. I donât remember much about third grade in 1970, but I knew my teacher loved me when it felt like no one else did, and that was enough to get me through a day. Iâve been teaching for 25 years now. Sometimes there are students who need to know their teacher loves them when no one else does. Sometimes they stay in at recess. Sometimes I play the guitar. â Hope Watterson
Author: Hope Watterson

Story Name: Embracing a New Life and Love
Story: When I lifted the baby girl to my chest, it was love, overwhelming and instant. Then came the Spider-Man light-up shoes. The short haircut. The six-pack of superhero undies from the boys section. The tantrums over having to wear a top at the pool. The revelation that a different life was possible. The trying of new names. The telling of family, friends, school. And now our love is different, new. The love of mother and her 8-year-old son. The loving of someone for who they truly are, not whom you had imagined them to be. â Kate Streip
Author: Kate Streip

Story: During my first shelter-in-place âdate,â I saw myself watching him looking at me on the video call. Despite my best efforts, I was consumed by my mannerisms. Do I always tilt my head like that? Does this look like a neutral smile and not a grimace? The experience was alienating and unsettling. It increased my anxiety and crippled our conversation. Still, we decided to meet for an in-person picnic, where I could only see his face, not mine. Weâve been dating since. â Kate Sautter
Author: Kate Sautter

Story: I met Ashley while moving a sofa out of a walk-up in Minneapolis. Six months later, we went to a political fund-raiser. The organizer asked us how we knew each other. I said we were friends. She said, âWeâre dating.â Later, I said, âAre we dating?â We had been spending all of our free time together, but I didnât know. Ashley said, âYes, youâre my girlfriend and Iâm your girlfriend. I was in love with you the moment I met you.â Weâre celebrating our anniversary this month. However, if you ask Ashley, she would say our celebration is long overdue. â Clare Baumgart
Author: Clare Baumgart

Story Name: An Open Purse on the Park Bench
Story: My grandmotherâs purse sat open and unattended on a park bench in the 1950s Bronx. Alarmed, my young mother said, âMom, your purse is open!â âItâs OK, honey,â my grandmother said. âIf someone takes it, they need it more than I do.â In that moment, my motherâs young world took on a new hue. They were a poor Jewish family of five living in a small two-bedroom apartment. They barely got by. Yet, my grandmother left her heart and purse open to those who needed it most. â Deborah L. Staunton
Author: Deborah L. Staunton

Story: My father, Seung-ho, has always had an eye for little details. About two months into sheltering-in-place, I asked him to grab me chocolate almond milk at the grocery store. When he came home with cashew milk, I started to complain that he got the wrong milk. He interrupted me, pointing to the bottom of the carton. There, in small text, it stated, âwith a touch of almond.â My annoyance melted into a wide grin because I knew how hard he must have looked to find the most almond-like milk available for me. â Rachael Lee
Author: Rachael Lee

Story Name: Three Stops on the Uptown Train
Story: Fifty-ninth Street subway platform. 6 p.m. The uptown train arrives. One car stops in front of me, another in front of him. Our stares are interrupted as we board the crowded train. He races closer to me, bumping into a mother holding a baby. He comforts the baby from crying, then keeps staring at me until my 77th Street stop. I get off. He holds his foot in the door to see if Iâll turn around. When I do, he jumps off. Forty-two years later, and married, we still look at each other with the same intensity. â Mark Wolk
Author: Mark Wolk

Story: When I was little, I would rush into my parentsâ room at night to ensure they were breathing. As I grew older, I became increasingly preoccupied by death: Why do we do anything if the end is inevitable? Filled with existential dread, Iâd burrow in bed for weeks. Eventually, my depressive fears found respite in knowledge. While completing my music therapy degree with an internship in hospice care, I met Seth, a registered nurse. After helping people die all day, we couldnât help but climb in bed and be alive, honoring what feels right, right now. â Sarah Ward
Author: Sarah Ward

Story: At 90, my mother found fiction, something she had scorned her entire life. A news-loving, quick-witted, born-and-bred New Yorker, she breathlessly followed current events. Who needs a newsfeed with her calling me at work to announce that Tim Russert died? After two cornea transplants at 88, my mother shifted her perspective on fiction â and life. With her new sight, she views the world through a more sentimental lens. Now open to the imaginary, she devours novels, which we discuss like schoolgirls, reveling in our shared refuge from reality. â Melissa Zeph
Author: Melissa Zeph

Story: The way a never-been-kissed 23-year-old feels on a dateâs couch is the same way the last unpopped popcorn kernel feels in the microwave. As an anxious and over-scheduled kernel, I always stopped the timer before the ideal mark. But on a walk with a coronavirus-free individual, I gained the courage to complete the cycle of electromagnetic waves. These past months of death and injustice have taught me that life is short. I never knew what would diminish my first-kiss fear. Turns out a pandemic is a really good microwave. â Kate Kesselman
Author: Kate Kesselman

Story: I sit in my motherâs bed in Michigan. She asks, âHow did I make you?â Her eyes are fresh flowers. Her thin arms are stems. âI came from your leg,â I answer. She has a long scar above her knee from an old accident. When we were young, she convinced my three sisters and me that this was how we were born. I run to the fridge before we continue our game. Nothing is there but a box, her hospice package. Morphine and pills. She has dementia and doesnât know sheâs dying. I do. Brave for love, I walk back in. â Nancy Shayne
Author: Nancy Shayne

Story: She saw me in college, found me online and told me I was cute. On our first date at a New Delhi cafe, her anxiety made her talk nonstop. We discussed how the world had so many children that we would never want to procreate. When I left the city to look for a better career, she insisted on dropping me at the railway station. It became our ritual whenever I visited. Those farewells were painful. But I never realized how grateful I was for her seeing me off until our final goodbye, when I was standing on the platform alone. â Manik Saggar
Author: Manik Saggar

Story: Anna was at the age when pebbles or crayons could symbolize our five family members. Sitting on my lap, she played with my necklace, a pendant of nesting rings. Her little fingers separated each silver loop. âThis circle is Daddy,â she said. âThis one is Ali, this one is Michael, this one is me.â She left me out. I felt an irrational, childish wisp of disappointment. Was my mothering meaningless, my love invisible? She paused, then touched the tiny circle that joined the others to the chain. âAnd this one is you, Mommy, because you hold us all together.â â Leah DeCesare
Author: Leah DeCesare

Story: Four years ago, a pair of sparrows built a nest in our microwave vent. My husband evicted them. They rebuilt. My husband gave up. The squawking squatters now return every May to raise a family. We hear their peeping while eating our oatmeal and watch the couple fly around our yard, looking for food for their brood. In October, we know by the sudden quiet that they and their children have left. We take solace in their ability to rebuild each year, happy to provide them with a love nest in a Connecticut vent. â Beth Levine
Author: Beth Levine

Story: After my release from the hospital, Patti stands in the doorway of my quarantined sickroom in Port Royal, S.C. I apologize for this mortifying virus, for causing her such deep grief and for needing to be waited on day and night. âDonât,â she says, tongue thick with hurt. âI love you.â Her response takes away my already-short breath as I suddenly understand my myopia: 52 years of marriage and I still think love must be earned. Outside my window, live oaks and Spanish moss sway. I look in her pooling eyes. Through this dark devastation, old love blossoms anew. â Steven Lewis
Author: Steven Lewis

Story: At 11, I was the youngest in the eating disorder program. In her 60s, Shelly was the oldest. Trapped in armchairs that smelled like scrambled eggs, we fiddled with everything: threads, tissues, clothing, beads. When a counselor confiscated my playthings, Shelly intervened: âSheâs just a baby.â After 100 days, I was released. Shelly pressed a bracelet into my palm â tiny, opalescent beads strung between two leather cords. Seven years later, my wrist is too big for Shellyâs bracelet. But looking at the beads nestled in the tough leather, I think of the young girl in the veteranâs arms. â Eliza Rudalevige
Author: Eliza Rudalevige

Story: On a sticky August Sunday, my boyfriend balanced my mattress on his electric skateboard. This is how he transported it two miles west across Manhattan to its new home. I swooned at his ingenuity, jogging behind him with a yellow Gatorade. We wove through traffic on First Avenue and past the busy fruit sellers. Old men in Central Park paused their chess game to applaud. Bikers cheered as we took the mattress down the pedestrian lane. After our hourlong odyssey, we kissed through our masks. This city that some are calling dead is very much alive. â Meghan Gunn
Author: Meghan Gunn

Story: Getting care packages at sleep-away camp felt like getting hugs through the mail. Gum, games and Mad Libs equaled instant, albeit fleeting, popularity. Now, from upstate New York, I return the favor to my mother at her senior residence in San Francisco. Dried apricots, bagels and lox, and masks show my love, but they cannot replace real contact, nor clear Californiaâs smoky air. Midway through summer camp, weâd watch each parentâs car pull up to find their camper. Hugs during those reunions were big and long. Please, are we midway through this ordeal yet? â Melissa McNeese
Author: Melissa McNeese

Story: Conor and I had just decided to go steady when his Canadian visa expired. He wanted me to return to Ireland with him. I didnât want him to be my only lifeline in an unfamiliar country. âLetâs go be starving artists in Berlin instead,â I said, half joking. Berlin was new to both of us. After moving, we didnât have much. We shared a small bed and a single pillow, but I was happy because he held me tight as we slept every night. Years later, on our queen bed with an excess of pillows, he still holds me like I would fall off if he didnât. â Sandy Yu
Author: Sandy Yu

Story Name: A Man of Many Tongues and Titles
Story: All night, my grandfather, Pepere, speaks in languages my family does not understand, claiming that dozens of robbers are breaking in or a concert is out on the deck. On unlucky dementia days, he confuses me for a past girlfriend, or puts the remote in the microwave. Pepere has earned many titles: World War II soldier, labor camp survivor, refugee to France and, most recently, 100-year-old grandfather. These days, my family focuses on the present, grateful for the warmth of his smile, the life of his language and the autumn of his age. â Abby Donnelly
Author: Abby Donnelly

Story Name: Itâs OK to Feel This Way
Story: He got sad first. In a sea of anxiety, he lost his sense of self and self-worth. Sometimes, I cradled him in my arms and covered his face with kisses.
